subject: Education
title: Chunking: How Experts Pack More In
description: A micro-lesson that makes Chunking: How Experts Pack More In usable.

hook.text: A chess master glances at a board for five seconds and recreates it perfectly.

buildup.text: Novices see 32 individual pieces. Experts see five or six familiar patterns.

discovery.text: George Miller showed working memory holds about four chunks, not four items.

twist.text: A chunk can be a letter or an entire sentenceâ€”it depends on your expertise.

climax.text: Building chunks through practice is how beginners become experts over time.

punchline.text: Experts don't have better memoryâ€”just bigger chunks.

quiz.question: What is a 'chunk' in cognitive science?
options: A meaningful group of items treated as one unit in memory
A physical section of the brain
A type of short-term memory loss
